summary:
Daario: I don’t understand ... I thought you said you couldn’t conceive a child.
Daenerys: Trust me, I’m as surprised as you...
body:
Daario: I don’t understand … I thought you said you couldn’t conceive a child.

Daenerys: Trust me, I’m as surprised as you are.

Daario: But the two of us, we…

Daenerys: I don’t know. What can I say? Either this baby fulfills an ancient prophesy to deliver the world from darkness, or the sun is now rising in the west and setting in the east.

Daario:

Daenerys: Or the witch was lying.

Daario:

Daenerys: Or you were shooting blanks the whole time.

Daario:

Daenerys:

Daario:

Daenerys:

Daario:

Daenerys:

Jon: Winter is ‘ere.

summary: Yes, it's a total fair critique for D&D, they should had respected more the material from the book and add more diversity with...
question: Yes, it's a total fair critique for D&D, they should had respected more the material from the book and add more diversity with CGI. I just think it's really sad how the haters go and use the 'white savior' for Daenerys when that was only a problem from that scene in the show and the character is not based on that, I feel like they reduce the importance of that storyline (a person borned as a princess, a noble, using her power and privilage to help and care for others) using that word
answer:
To me, I get when people say they are tired of the whole white people going to save poc from themselves trope and D&D messed up a bit with that in the show. I can understand that, but I don’t think Dany herself is a racist, and especially not in the books (which is way more diverse and has more balance between white and poc in the areas she has travelled to).  

A lot of Dany haters do use the term sloppily because they hate Dany, and not because they necessarily care about the trope itself. I’ve seen it with the imperialism and colonialism critiques as well. You can’t say imperialism is wrong and then give another great house a pass for it (cough cough Starks) for engaging in imperialism for example.

I agree that Dany is a great example of someone that comes to power and isn’t perfect, but she does try and genuinely help people. She’s young, but I think she has the potential and will to bring great change to Westeros and I am one hundred percent rooting for her.

summary: Emilia Clarke: “Para ser Daenerys hay que tener muchos cojones”
title: Emilia Clarke: “Para ser Daenerys hay que tener muchos cojones”
excerpt: La actriz de 'Juego de Tronos' habla con EL ESPAÑOL sobre la última temporada y el fenómeno en torno a la serie de HBO.
description:
I have seen the fake concern in certain crackhead shippers on this fandom, going around saying shit about Emilia because she feels sad over ending an iconic run with her own character along with other nominations.  Since probably most of them have 3 brains cells, two of them dedicated to hating Daenerys and now Emilia, let me translate this other interview that was done in the same day that the English outlets were done because this one is so cheerful about Daenerys and her iconic feminist run:

Emilia Clarke: “To be Daenerys you have to have a lot of balls" 

(…) Despite the seriousness of her character, who barely laughs, Clarke exudes sympathy. She gestures, jokes and is looking forward to doing more comedy. EL ESPAÑOL was able to chat with her in London, where she laughed and commented to a group of journalists that it is a pity that "she doesn’t make jokes”. “I wanted to joke more often, the truth … And we tried, we tried to have Dany say something funny in the series. They told me: you are very funny, we are going to try it, and we did it and I can say no, it did not work, her character is not that funny. She is many things, but it is not funny” she said laughing.

(…) She has grown up with her character to become a Khaleesi of her own "This character has changed me a lot as a woman, I didn’t even know what I was doing before. Now I realize that I didn’t know anything at all when I started. I did not know about the industry, or acting, or about society or politics," says the actress. 

Daenerys is a character who broke the rules of television, put a woman in the place where we have only seen men before, and Clarke, therefore, appreciates the challenge of having given her life. "She has allowed me to do so many things… Daenerys has many scenes in which she says such great speeches in front of many people, with a very high level… but I am Emilia, and I had to say those speeches in front of 300 extras in an invented language and sound convincing, and to do all that she does, she has to have a lot of strength, she has to have lots of balls! (cojones)” she says the word in Spanish proving that the months of filming in our country have taken effect “and she has allowed me to do that, with that she has also allowed me to walk on fire, literally. As an actress, what you usually do is say phrases and be in your brand, when they ask me I usually describe my work that way, but with SHE, I have done all those things” she says.

(…) We tell the anecdote to Emilia Clarke, and she celebrates with her arms raised and congratulating herself that her character has entered those circles (They were talking about how a princess in Spain used a T-shirt with the theme “I’m not a queen, I’m a Khaleesi”). "It is a series that speaks of power, which puts women in a position of power, and that is unique. Game of Thrones is a political series. It is fantasy, yes, but it is putting women in that position of power and that resonates for any current situation in which there are women. That’s very nice because we talk about a fantasy world, but in essence, it talks about believing in an idea and having people who support you and become someone capable of leading armies, and that is similar in reality. As the issue of social division, there are many parallels that do not cost much to draw.”

How could Emilia not feel sad to say goodbye to one of the most iconic female characters of our time? The others interviews that antis are using have nothing to do with the character’s ending, but mostly how Emilia feels about the ending of her lifetime job, and finally saying goodbye to half of her life and a character that changed grounds in fantasy and television. 

Yes, Dany is a woman in a position of power, and a woman who is changing everything around her and Emilia understands her plenty.

blog.name: mayaofatlantis
blog.title: This Woman Has A Name
blog.description: XXVII | Black American | Christian | Period Drama | History | Marvel & DC | Fantasy & Sci-Fi | Etc

summary: You know book and tv show watchers, it’s perfectly fine to not like Daenerys. I don’t mind people criticizing her ruling because...
body:
You know book and tv show watchers, it’s perfectly fine to not like Daenerys.

I don’t mind people criticizing her ruling because she isn’t perfect at all. I have my criticisms of her in both the book and show. 

It’s more than fine (and in mores the show were D&D screwed up and turned slavery into race based and had Dany surfing on brown people) not to like the white savior aspect of her storyline. I don’t think Dany is racist, but I can see the argument about her storyline.

However, when y’all hold double standards where you give passes to all the other male claimants that want the iron throne and bash Dany? We have a problem.

When you make direct connections to white supremacy in real life regarding game of thrones and then turn around and complain about slave owners dying at the hands of Daenerys? We have a problem. 

I have a problem with people hollering about Dany being blood thirsty because she killed people in a war or her enemies, but then people have all sorts of understanding for slave owning trash that mutilate, rape, beat, and kill slaves. I definitely have a problem with that and you will find a lot of other Dany fans who do as well.

And I do have a problem with so called “feminists”  saying that Dany “bragged” about her rape. That’s sexism period. And you are a despicable person if you saw that scene and thought that was “bragging”.

Like who you like and root for who you want to root for. 

But don’t give me sexist double standards or critiques where people are sympathizing with slave owners and then claim to hate white supremacy. 

Fandom has no place for that kind of behavior period.

Ps. If you don’t like Daenerys. Stay out of her tags!

I have a problem with people hollering about Dany being blood thirsty because she killed people in a war or her enemies, but then people have all sorts of understanding for slave owning trash that mutilate, rape, beat, and kill slaves. I definitely have a problem with that and you will find a lot of other Dany fans who do as well.

And I do have a problem with so called “feminists”  saying that Dany “bragged” about her rape. That’s sexism period. And you are a despicable person if you saw that scene and thought that was “bragging”.

Like who you like and root for who you want to root for. 

But don’t give me sexist double standards or critiques where people are sympathizing with slave owners and then claim to hate white supremacy. 

Fandom has no place for that kind of behavior period.

Ps. If you don’t like Daenerys. Stay out of her tags!

trail.content_raw:
You know book and tv show watchers, it’s perfectly fine to not like Daenerys.

I don’t mind people criticizing her ruling because she isn’t perfect at all. I have my criticisms of her in both the book and show. 

It’s more than fine (and in mores the show were D&D screwed up and turned slavery into race based and had Dany surfing on brown people) not to like the white savior aspect of her storyline. I don’t think Dany is racist, but I can see the argument about her storyline.

However, when y’all hold double standards where you give passes to all the other male claimants that want the iron throne and bash Dany? We have a problem.

When you make direct connections to white supremacy in real life regarding game of thrones and then turn around and complain about slave owners dying at the hands of Daenerys? We have a problem. 

I have a problem with people hollering about Dany being blood thirsty because she killed people in a war or her enemies, but then people have all sorts of understanding for slave owning trash that mutilate, rape, beat, and kill slaves. I definitely have a problem with that and you will find a lot of other Dany fans who do as well.

And I do have a problem with so called “feminists”  saying that Dany “bragged” about her rape. That’s sexism period. And you are a despicable person if you saw that scene and thought that was “bragging”.

Like who you like and root for who you want to root for. 

But don’t give me sexist double standards or critiques where people are sympathizing with slave owners and then claim to hate white supremacy. 

Fandom has no place for that kind of behavior period.

Ps. If you don’t like Daenerys. Stay out of her tags!
trail.content:
You know book and tv show watchers, it’s perfectly fine to not like Daenerys.

I don’t mind people criticizing her ruling because she isn’t perfect at all. I have my criticisms of her in both the book and show. 

It’s more than fine (and in mores the show were D&D screwed up and turned slavery into race based and had Dany surfing on brown people) not to like the white savior aspect of her storyline. I don’t think Dany is racist, but I can see the argument about her storyline.

However, when y’all hold double standards where you give passes to all the other male claimants that want the iron throne and bash Dany? We have a problem.

When you make direct connections to white supremacy in real life regarding game of thrones and then turn around and complain about slave owners dying at the hands of Daenerys? We have a problem. 

I have a problem with people hollering about Dany being blood thirsty because she killed people in a war or her enemies, but then people have all sorts of understanding for slave owning trash that mutilate, rape, beat, and kill slaves. I definitely have a problem with that and you will find a lot of other Dany fans who do as well.

And I do have a problem with so called “feminists”  saying that Dany “bragged” about her rape. That’s sexism period. And you are a despicable person if you saw that scene and thought that was “bragging”.

Like who you like and root for who you want to root for. 

But don’t give me sexist double standards or critiques where people are sympathizing with slave owners and then claim to hate white supremacy. 

Fandom has no place for that kind of behavior period.

Ps. If you don’t like Daenerys. Stay out of her tags!
